title: [eeschema] symbol properties tab order  (lp:#1843540)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1843540) created by **Mitja Nemec (mitjan)**
```
tab order in the symbol properties dialog in eeschema could be improved

When you open a dialog the selected item is the reference value field.
Hiting the tab move the selection along the columns and it stops in the
last column (text size). A minor improvement would be if the selection
would move to the next line, but even better it would be if it firstly move
along the lines and after the last line it would skip to the new column in
the first line.

I find that the footprint value field is the one I edit the most often, and
when having the footprint name in the clipboard this would enable me to
copy paste the value faster.
```

title: Add a warning for case sensitive differences (lp:#1843415)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1843415) created by **Dino Ghilardi (dino-ghilardi)**
```
If you name two hierarchical sheets with (very) similar names, like
"file1.sch" and "File1.sch", this will work on case sensitive file systems,
while it can generate errors in case insensitive file systems.

Although using filenames as such (mostly identical names for different
sheets) is not a good practice, it is still "legal" in eeschema, and
copying the project from a case-sensitive machine (i.e. Linux) to a case-
insensitive machine (i.e. dos/win) will lead to differences in the
behaviour.
For instance, if the two names refer to one child sheet and its parent this
will create a circular dependency on schematics and likely crash eeschema
on windows machines but not on Linux machines.

Cheers,
Dino.
```
Original tags: eeschema starter

title: eeschema - 'symbol fields'-editor  - linebreak in a component field makes schematic unreadable  (lp:#1842943)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1842943) created by **Otto Mikkonen (ottomaani138)**
```
When working with the new 'symbol fields'-editor in eeschema, I've
experienced a breakage of the associated .sch-file due to linebreaks
appearing on one of the component-fields.

I'm not exactly sure from where these linebreaks appear, but they somehow
make their way into the fields when copying component field-data from one
part to another. Somehow selecting a field graphically and copy-pasting it
to another sometimes selects a hidden linebreak, which then partially
breaks the associated .sch file. Could also be, that the linebreak
originates from an external source, like the part# from mouser.com.

Anyways, since these linebreaks can be so disastrous, I thought some added
resilience to how fields are managed would be neat. I.e., when linebreak is
encountered on a component field, it could be filtered out before saving
the .sch or something. I can't imagine a case, when linebreak is actually
wanted on a component field.

I added a screenshot on how the error-messages might look like when trying
to open up a broken schematic.
```

description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1842654) created by **Tiago Filipe Gala da Silva (tiago-gala-j)**
```
I do a lot of LED boards and most of the board is done based on Copper
Zones.
Since there are a lot of repetitive parts of the circuit, I layout the
zones for the first 2 LEDs and then duplicate (no copy/paste) the copper
zones for the remaining LEDs. After placing the zones I edit each one
manually to give them the proper NET.

Sometimes, after changing the NET for the copper zone, when pressing the OK
button, a dialog comes up with the following error:

> Warning
> Orientation must be at least -180 deg.

This dialog only haves a OK button.

I believe this only has happened on duplicated zones and I haven't found a
pattern to reproduce this issue, but I had it happen on zones with only
duplication.

I can only make the error go away by deleting the zone
```

title: Documentation: Build instructions incomplete/improvement (lp:#1842626)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1842626) created by **Michael Weigel (michaelw87)**
```
The documentation on building could be improved:

a) Excluding various build targets: The documentation states the flag, e.g.
"KICAD_SPICE" which can be used to exclude (or include) something, but
doesn't show, how (e.g. "To specifically override any of the build targets,
set the specific flag by adding '-D<YourFlag>=<Value>', e.g.
"-DKICAD_SPICE=0" in the cmake line below"

b) Default to more than a single-core build:
The build instruction says to use "make", which defaults to a single-core
build. Shouldn't that be "make -j <NumberOfCpuCores>"? Or at least a
recommendation that it can be used or why it shouldn't (if there is a
reason, not to)

c) USE_CCACHE: I know this from using android, which is why I explicitely
searched for it, and it indeed exists. A description of it and a default
usage (not by setting the flag, but by defaulting the build instructions to
using it) would be nice, imo

d) Exact packages: Most homepages for the additionally required packages
allow downloading windows binaries and source code for linux. I don't want
to source-build everything, there are prebuilts, so it would be nice to get
list of actual linux packages to install, e.g. "libglew-dev" for GLEW etc.

These have all occured to me while trying to set up and getting a build.
I hope this is still the right place for it. I didn't want to do a single
report for each of these, as they are targetting the same thing, hope this
is OK.
```

title: PlEditor: Pressing M on an already moving item shifts the item from the cursor (lp:#1842623)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1842623) created by **Michael Weigel (michaelw87)**
```
I am not sure if this is the right place for reporting bugs against the
master branch, but I'll try it anyway:

- Open PageLayoutEditor
- Hover over an existing item (e.g. the "Title: %T" element at X=109mm,
Y=10.7mm) and press "M"
-> Item is following the cursor when moving around
- Press "M" again
-> Item is now "gone", see the coordinates in the properties-frame: it's
now at somewhere X=-150, Y=263, so at a normal zoom level you won't see the
item anymore. It's still following the mouse and can be dropped with left-
click

Correct: Already ongoing item movement doesn't allow starting another
movement.
Two possible behaviours expected:
a) "M" does nothing when already moving an item
b) "M" drops the item at the current cursor position, making it not only
the start of an action but also allows stopping the action with the same
key

This has been experienced with a build against the "master" branch of
yesterday, checked out at commit 79d062aefcdeda4305e50a595e69dfca33bbee06
(+ some fixes on pcb_new so it doesn't error on build)
```

title: Schematic junction implementation (lp:#1842438)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1842438) created by **eelik (eelik)**
```
The next is copied from https://bugs.launchpad.net/kicad/+bug/1842355.

I'm not sure if this is the right place to talk about this, but I find the
concept of independent junction dot weird. Junction should be a property of
two or more wires crossing (or endpoints touching, or endpoint touching
another line) and there shouldn't exist any junction without two wire
lines.

From the standpoint of implementation it may be easier to have separate
junctions but they should very strictly depend on existence of a wire
crossing. For example, instead of

junction: xcoord,ycoord

there could be

junction:
   wire: id
   wire: id

But at least, if they are separate independent entities, they should be
updated very stricly with any change made to wires. The update mechanism
should be "waterproof". I've seen different situations when junction don't
correctly reflect changes made to the wires.

It shouldn't be possible to add junctions where there are no wires
crossing, and there should never be need to remove junctions except from
where wires are crossing. "Add junction" shouldn't blindly add a junction
dot, it should only make a junction out of two wires crossing each other.
```

description:

```
In master branch, the error "Mismatch between hierarchical labels and pin
sheets" is not issued anymore. In stable versions (5.1.2 and 5.1.4) still
works.

To reproduce it:
1)create a new hierarchical sheet
2) add a hier. pin with "Place hierarchical pin in sheet"
3) inside the child sheet place a resistor and connect it to two
hierarchical labels with a name different from the one in the parent sheet
block (call them both "a")
4) Run the ERC: No error is issued.

(attached file: the project with this issue)

Running ERC on the same file using stable version you get 3 errors for
"Mismatch between hierarchical labels": correct. (also two more errors that
are not correct, subject for another minor bug report)

error is reported to work correctly.
```

title: Can't tune pcb trace length to be over 2147mm (lp:#1842367)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1842367) created by **Harvie (harvie)**
```
I need to create PCB with ridiculously long traces (4000 to 8000mm) and i
wanted kicad to generate the zig-zag pattern for me, so i've tried "tune
track length" feature. But it turns out the longest trace i can do is
2147mm, 2148mm and more can't be done.

Can you please increase this?

According to IRC it's probably caused by internal representation of length
in micrometers as signed 32 bit number... So i understand it might be hard
to increase.

Thank you
```

title: Idea: compatibility section in file formats (contains warning texts to be printed when opened in older versions) (lp:#1842285)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1842285) created by **Rene Poeschl (poeschlr)**
```
I just discovered a possibly useful feature in the eagle file format. They
include a section called compatibility which contains warnings to be
printed if opened in an older version.

Might be something interesting to add to kicad to prepare for a time when
the file format becomes much more stable than it is now (If only minor
additions are made then these can possibly ignored by the user. But the
user would need to know what they loose by opening in an older version.
This is one way of telling an older version which warning messages to print
without the older version even being aware of the features it does not
support.)

It could theoretically also include information for the parser on how to
replace some unknown things such that they can parse the file kind of
safely.

For example it could contain information which file format tags can be
ignored without changing the outputed file. The differential net clearance
setting added with v5 would be such an example. Ignoring it does not change
the viewed file it only removes a routing feature.

Chamfered pads are a different beast. They would only be able to be
replaced by another similar pad type and therefore change the file ->
should be an error. But instead of a parser error it would then say "you
use a kicad version that does not understand chamfered pads introduced in
version 6.0.0." which is much easier to understand by the user. (in reality
a warning could then only be produced by 7.x features as 5.x and earlier
does not understand this feature. But i have no example for such a future
release.)
```

title: wishlist: eeschema: don't un-annotate on cut-and-paste (lp:#1842275)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1842275) created by **Dino Ghilardi (dino-ghilardi)**
```
In the current master version, when you cut and paste a part of a
schematic, it is un-annotated. On copy-paste that is good since you are
always adding components, but in a cut-paste it may let you loose some of
the work done.

Example:
You have a fully routed (complex) board.
You need to re-organize schematics moving some components from one sheet to
another, so you use "cut and paste" to do this.
When you paste the components they get un-annotated
When you re-synchronize the pcb you need to re-annotate components, then
the components you moved/reannotated are removed and put back as "new"
components with new reference, loosing the previous placement, so you need
to place the components once again. Also if the components get the same
reference they are removed and re-inserted as new components when you re-
syncronize the pcb.



Cheers,
Dino.

Note: may be this wish is related to Bug #1827503 "Implement more (and
custom?) annotation schemes"
```
Original tags: eeschema ui

title: Timestamp generation unsafe for scripting, year 2038 (lp:#1842253)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1842253) created by **Simon Richter (sjr)**
```
Looking at GetNewTimeStamp() in the aptly named common/common.cpp, this
takes the lower 32 bits (as that is the definition of timestamp_t) of
current Unix time and, if needed, increments it to avoid collisions when
multiple components are created in the same second:

    timestamp_t GetNewTimeStamp()
    {
        static timestamp_t oldTimeStamp;
        timestamp_t newTimeStamp;
        newTimeStamp = time( NULL );
        if( newTimeStamp <= oldTimeStamp )
            newTimeStamp = oldTimeStamp + 1;
        oldTimeStamp = newTimeStamp;
        return newTimeStamp;
    }

This is reasonably safe for GUI operation, as we can assume that it is
unlikely that the user creates a large number of components, then closes
and reopens the program, and proceeds to add more components.

When eeschema gains scripting support, this might fall flat though when one
script creates a large array of components and subsequently terminates (so
the record of the highest ID in use is lost), and the user then starts
another script or begins editing manually.

This will also break down in 2038, when the 32-bit counter wraps around.
This is less of a collision risk, but we lose ordering.

Two changes, both somewhat beginner friendly:

 - find out why we're limited to 32 bits and what needs to be done to
change this.

It should be safe to replace timestamp_t by time_t, but there was probably
a good reason why that wasn't done. This needs some archaeology.

 - Move oldTimeStamp into the SCH_SHEET class and update it during load.

This requires that everyone generating timestamps does so with a sheet as
context, and there might need to be some handling for duplicate timestamps
on different sheets.

It might also make sense to stop generating identifiers from the current
time and just use incrementing numbers -- but we need to get better at
detecting duplicates then.
```

description:

```
Ver: (5.1.2)-2 release build, pcbnew

Current arc tool works on a sequence of;
1-) specifying the center of the arc.
2-) selecting the start and end points of the arc.

Radius is calculated based on the center and start point entered by the
user through GUI.

This works well if the center of the arc easyly entered (graphically).

In case of very large radiuses and the start/end points are determined by
other elements (consider mechanical Edge.Cuts), the current method is not
very helpfull.

Request of an arc tool option to enter Start and End points on the GUI,
then provide the radius as number (or drag the mouse whlist reporting the
radius on the screen).

For an example: see the PCB digram(for Edge.Cuts) in
https://www.hammfg.com/files/parts/pdf/1553ABK.pdf
See the given arc with R190.5mm

Many thanks...
```

title: Board print out for identical components for assembly purposes (lp:#1841945)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1841945) created by **Art (diametrix)**
```
When I do a manual assembly of a prototype, I usually have to use different
color markers for multiple identical footprints (components) to speed up
the assembly.  It is especially useful if assembling multiple prototypes.

For example, if I have five identical 10K resistors in the schematic I will
highlight them with the same color in the board printout and in the BOM, so
I can populate them all at the same time.  The problem is - it takes time
and eventually you run out of colors.  It would be a neat feature if you
could automatically print a board layout with identical components printed
in bold and the rest of the board greyed out all on separate sheets.

For example, when I print a board layout for the assembly purposes I print
only silkscreen, paste, Fob and mask layers for each side of the board.
Let's say you have a check box in the print dialog to collate sheets based
on the components.  When checked, instead of one page print you will get as
many pages as there are unique components on the board, with each page
containing all the layers I selected to be printed and only the current set
of components printed in bold and the rest of the board greyed out (still
visible but barely)
```

title: Footprint editor fails to read footprints from library (lp:#1841782)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1841782) created by **Dave Vandenbout (devb)**
```
I have an fp-lib-table with 1,087 entries for libraries which are all
stored locally. When I first open the footprint editor, there is a
20-second delay as all the libraries are scanned. After that, I can open
footprints from individual libraries with no problem.

After *closing and then re-opening* the main KiCad application, re-opening
the footprint editor does the following:
 1) There is no delay for scanning the 1,087 libraries. The progress
indicator appears and disappears quickly.
 2) All the libraries appear in the left-hand pane, but clicking on the "+"
by a library name causes it to change to a "-" while failing to show the
individual footprints within that library (i.e. the footprints do not
appear below the library name as a drop-down list).

This problem persists even after re-installing the KiCad application.

I can make the problem disappear by reducing my fp-lib-table file to 116 or
fewer libraries. Any more than that and the problem returns.

I can also make the problem disappear for the entire list of 1,087
libraries if I include at least one library that is fetched from Github
instead of locally. That seems to cause the footprint editor to scan the
entire list of libraries (which takes about 20 seconds).
```

title: Hierarchical pins and hierarchical box move during rotation (lp:#1841714)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1841714) created by **Johannes (jos+)**
```
Version (5.99.0-23-gcde9a788b-dirty)


Section I
-----------
Commands used R, M, Ctrl+Z, mouse (video attached)

o Always the very first pin name only, when moved aligns the sheet/file
name texts with its
  orientation. Regardless of left or right position as starting point.

o Any subsequent moves of different pin names seems fine.

o The selected box walks away with every R command.

o A sequence of R, M (pin close to edge), and R on a pin name will
eventually place that pin outside
  the box. The closer the pin is placed to the edge the further away it
moves. However, a subsequent
  M will snap it back inside the box.


Section II
------------
Commands X, Y (without video)

o Y command on an unselected (mouse hovers over it) box walks the box to
the right.

o Y on a selected (highlighted) box walks the box at its width to the left.
  A subsequent select (highlight) will then walk the box to the right.

o X issued moves seem fine.

Cheers
```

title: Clean up preprocessor symbols around GLM includes (lp:#1841610)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1841610) created by **Simon Richter (sjr)**
```
Probably a task for someone experienced with C++ and CMake, but doesn't
need familiarity with the KiCad codebase.

When KiCad is compiled with link time optimization, several warnings are
reported for the 3D viewer, where data types are different between
translation units that are later linked. This doesn't seem to have adverse
effects, as these different definitions seem to be compatible, but it is
still an indication that something is not entirely correct.

Since GLM has some compile time options configured through preprocessor
macros, my expectation is that the macros it is sensitive to are not
consistent around all uses of the GLM library. The warning messages
themselves point to different implementations of the glm::vec3 type being
used:

/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/linux-kicad-head-
lto/src/include/plugins/3dapi/c3dmodel.h:57:3: warning: type 'struct
SMATERIAL' violates the C++ One Definition Rule [-Wodr]
 } SMATERIAL;
   ^
/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/linux-kicad-head-
lto/src/include/plugins/3dapi/c3dmodel.h:57:3: note: a different type is
defined in another translation unit
 } SMATERIAL;
   ^
/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/linux-kicad-head-
lto/src/include/plugins/3dapi/c3dmodel.h:39:13: note: the first difference
of corresponding definitions is field 'm_Ambient'
     SFVEC3F m_Ambient;          //
             ^
/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/linux-kicad-head-
lto/src/include/plugins/3dapi/c3dmodel.h:39:13: note: a field of same name
but different type is defined in another translation unit
     SFVEC3F m_Ambient;          //
             ^
/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/linux-kicad-head-
lto/src/include/plugins/3dapi/xv3d_types.h:47:25: note: type 'struct
SFVEC3F' should match type 'struct SFVEC3F'
 typedef glm::vec3       SFVEC3F;
                         ^
```

title: wishlist: eeschema block select for hierarchical sheet pins (lp:#1841555)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1841555) created by **Dino Ghilardi (dino-ghilardi)**
```
Problem: selecting a lot of hierarchical sheet pins can be time consuming,
since the block selection on hierarchical sheet pins seems not implemented
(or does not work).

Using shift+leftclick or ctrl+leftclick works, but needs to select the pins
one-by-one and can be tedious when you modified the schematic and you have
to delete or move a lot of pins.
In current version CTRL+click and SHIFT+click act the same way on sheet pin
selection.

Wish 1:
Enable the block selection on hierarchical sheet pins.

Wish 2:
Have shift and ctrl work as in "list" selection: clicking on a pin item and
shift-clicking on another would select all the pins between them on the
border of the hierarchical child sheet.  The default behaviour could be
"clockwise", so changing the order of the selected two mostly inverts the
selection.

Any of the two wishes solves the problem.

P.S.: ctrl-clicking on an item behaviour is good as it is now.

Possible problems: without a selection filter to choose if you want to
select or not hierarchical sheet pins, block selection could lead to
"strange" behaviours, for instance when you want to "block select" a part
of the schematics and get a multiple selection of components, wires and
some hierarchical sheet pins.

Cheers,
Dino.

----------------------------------------------------
```

```
the attached minimal example, but it seems like it does not remove the
redundant vias and track segmnts.

I guess the reason why it does not do anything on the vias and segments is
that they are not exactly on the same location. This may be ok, but should
we consider to enable some kind of "epsilon" for the matching that can be
set by the user?

The pcb was created in kicad by copy pasting stuff from multiple almost
exact files, hence they are slightly offset as it is sometimes hard to get
the alignment exact.
```

title: group buses incorrectly handle braces  (lp:#1840834)
description:
[Original report](https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1840834) created by **Brendan Haines (brendanhaines)**
```
When using {braces} notation of buses, the first name gets messed up by the
open brace.

BUSNAME{A B C}
should mean a bus with 3 members: "A", "B", and "C"
it instead is interpreted as having members: "brace}A", "B", and "C"

This incorrect interpretation is applied as follows:
Labels and hierarchical ports add "brace}" invisibly as above.
Hierarchical sheet pins act differently. Using the "import hierarchical
sheet pin" automatically inserts "brace}" which (unlike labels/ports) can
be seen and removed by editing the pin but does not appear in the text in
the schematic.

My current workaround is to add an extra bus member "A" to the beginning of
every bus and add "brace}" to every hierarchical sheet pin.

To connect using a bus from within one hierarchical sheet to another
requires the following names:
wire BUSNAME.B
bus BUSNAME{A B}
hierarchical label BUSNAME{A B}
hierarchical sheet pin BUSNAME{brace}A B}        << Note this is different
bus BUSNAME{A B}
wire BUSNAME.B


I will follow up with some pictures.


Ubuntu 19.04
```
